msgSnippet: ... Actually, I ll just jump to Cedric s defence here... TestNG isn t just used for unit tests, it s used for all sorts of tests including long-running
messageBody:
On 30/11/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> > On 11/29/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > > Cedric, but 2 + 2 still going to be 4 and you still will have to
> > > investigate why above 10 cases failed...
> >
> >
> > Yes, but you know exactly where to start when you read "1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS"
> > as opposed to "10 FAILURES".
>
> ...unless you're practising TDD, in which case you know exactly where to
> look: at whatever you just typed.

Actually, I'll just jump to Cedric's defence here... TestNG isn't just
used for unit tests, it's used for all sorts of tests including
long-running integration tests. TDD doesn't really apply there,
because the window may well be several hours.

Using dependencies (of some form) to prevent long-running tests from
running when you know they will (probably) fail anyway is a good idea.
However, it doesn't assist the developer at the point where they need
to diagnose failure that much.

This is, of course, why serious JUnit developers focus on dividing
tests into fast and slow. :) It's also why we don't tend to see a need
for other categories.
